chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: Data needs to be contained, clean and complete to be useful in today's workplace. The Power*MatchMaker is the tool that allows you to get a consolidated view of your customers, products or other key dimensions. This tool will help to provide you with clean data, build connections between disconnected data sources and to provide a single view for each customer, product or person by creating conformed dimensions. The Power*Matchmaker can even deal with different source systems that use different identifiers for the same customer, product or person.

Power*Matchmaker allows you to successfully build conformed dimensions which results in having concise and complete views of key dimensions. This aids executives and decision-makers in seeing the complete picture and allows them to make informed decisions based on the entire set of available data. The Power*MatchMaker builds conformed dimensions and eliminates duplicates from your database.

The Power*Matchmaker is a user-friendly and highly intuitive data consolidating tool. The tool is created by data warehouse designers, and has many features geared for anyone dealing with data, including:

listitem.para: Accepts user-defined data matching criteria
Allows for user confirmation of duplicates through the on-line verification facility
Builds cross-reference tables to link source systems' identifiers (PK's) to the target database identifiers
Merges duplicate records and their related data
Allows for Backup of impacted records prior to merging of data

Power*Matchmaker can be run against the entire database to perform initial data cleanup, or they can be incorporated into the data load process to identify and eliminate potential duplicates on an ongoing basis.
Whether you're building a Data Warehouse, Data Mart or a CRM system, the Power*MatchMaker will go a long way towards ensuring the integrity of your data for your decision support environment.

section.title: Drivers
section.para:
Most programs need a distinct driver program to communicate with each different type of database. The Power*Matchmaker uses Java-based drivers, which normally come from the database vendor in the form of "JAR"
Java Archive files; these are an extension to the file format used by PKZip/WinZip archives
files. You need to inform Power*Matchmaker about each driver before you can use it; do this from the JDBC Drivers window that can be accessed from the Database Connection Manager window. If you do not have the JDBC driver for a given database, you can usually obtain one from the database vendor. If that fails, you can find a directory of databases drivers on
Sun's web site
.

section.title: Projects
section.para: There are 3 different types of Power*Matchmaker projects that you can use to work with your data.

section.title: Find Duplicates Projects
section.para: This type of project allows you to identify and merge duplicate records that are found within the same table in the database.

section.title: Cleanse Projects
section.para: This type of project allows you to reformat data to create a more uniform and professional appearance.

section.title: Cross Reference Projects
section.para: This type of project allows you to create a cross referencing table that links two different tables together. The new table will relate the primary key from one table to the primary key of the other related table to show the relationship between the two records.

section.title: Munge
section.para: The term Munge means to transform and manipulate data. Munging is a method used throughout the Power*MatchMaker as preparation for the project actions. Within the Power*MatchMaker application, Munging is broken down into Munge Processes and Munge Steps.

section.title: Munge Processes
section.para: Munge Processes are the collections of individual Munge Steps that perform data manipulation. In each Munge Process, there are at least one input and one output Munge Steps. Various intermediate steps are added to modify the data.

section.title: Munge Steps
section.para: Munge steps are the individual data manipulation actions.

listitem.para: This step allows you to join the contents of multiple inputs. The output is the result of the join.

para.emphasis: Double Metaphone, Metaphone, Refined Soundex, Soundex

listitem.para: These are steps that code the given data phonetically according to their corresponding algorithms.
These are steps that convert the given data to the appropriate case.
This step removes all occurrences of characters in the given data not specified by the user.
This step replaces all occurrences of a user specified word to another in the data.
This step returns a part of the given data
This step returns a subset of each word from the given data.
This step replaces all occurrences of words with other words as specified by translate words set up by you.
This step counts the number of words in the given data.

section.title: Munge Pen
section.para: This is the area where you will create Munge Processes. This is done in a user-friendly environment by a simple drag-and-drop of your required Munge Steps.

section.title: Merge
section.para: The term Merge refers to the action of combining duplicate records into single records. Within the Power*MatchMaker application, this is done with Merge Rules.

section.title: Table Merge Rules
section.para: Table Merge Rules are collections of individual Column Merge Rules that deal with merging data in a database table. The two types of Table Merge Rules are Source Table Merge Rules and Related Table Merge Rules.

listitem.para: These are the essential rules that deal with the Merging on the source table in the database.
These are the additional rules that deal with the Merging on children, grandchildren or other related tables of the source table in the database.

section.title: Column Merge Rules
section.para: Column Merge Rules contains the Merging instructions for a specific column in the database. The possible Merging actions for Column Merge Rules are: use the master value, augment nulls, concatenate the values, use the maximum value, minimum value, and to set the sum as the value.

section.title: Engines
section.para: These are the components of the application that does the actual work on the database when they are ran.

section.title: Match Engine
section.para: The Match Engine finds the duplicate records in the database based on the data from the results of Munging.

section.title: Merge Engine
section.para: The Merge Engine combines the duplicate records in the database according to the Merge actions specified in the Merge Rules.

section.title: Cleansing Engine
section.para: The Cleansing Engine replaces the records in the database with the reformatted data from the results of Munging.

section.title: Translation
section.para: The term Translate usually refers to the action of expressing in different words. In the Power*MatchMaker, Translation helps you to search and replace words with a different term. A common use would be to replace abbreviations with the corresponding words. Translation is broken down in the Power*MatchMaker into Translation Groups and Translate Words.

section.title: Translation Groups
section.para: Translation Groups are the collections of the individual Translate Words. Each group should but are not limited to holding all related Translate Words.

section.title: Translate Words
section.para: Translate Words contains the individual instruction on the words to replace and the replacement term.

section.title: Who this book is for
section.para: This book is a step-by-step guide on how to use the full capabilities of Power*Matchmaker. It covers topics from how to install the Power*MatchMaker through setting up database connections to running Munge Processes.
We assume you are familiar with basic database terms. If you meet any terms that are unfamiliar, please refer to the Glossary at the end of this book.
This book also assumes you are familiar with basic computer operations.
We also assume you have SQL Power's Power*Matchmaker software installed on your computer; if not, please refer to the Installation Guide below.

section.title: Power*Matchmaker Prerequisites
section.para:
To run the Power*Matchmaker you need a Java 1.5 or newer Java Runtime ("Java VM" or "JVM"). A current version of the Java VM for common platforms can be obtained from
Sun Microsystems
. To ensure that your JVM is up-to-date, Apple Macintosh users should use Software Update (from the Apple Menu) while others should use the Java Updater (from, e.g., the Microsoft Windows Control Panel).

section.title: How to Obtain the Power*Matchmaker Software
section.para:
Power*Matchmaker can be obtained from the
download section
of the
SQLPower Website
. You should only need to download one file, choosing the platform-appropriate distribution (Windows-Installer for Microsoft Windows, "DMG" for Apple Macintosh, and ".tar.gz" for UNIX/Linux/other platforms). You should normally choose the download with the highest revision number available.

section.para: Double click on the Matchmaker-setup-Windows-n.m.jar. This will launch the Microsoft Windows installer. Follow the on-screen instructions.

section.title: Other Platforms
section.para: Extract the Matchmaker-generic-n.m.tar.gz package into the desired directory.

section.para: From the start menu, select All Programs. Then select the Power Loader Suite program group. Finally click on the Power shortcut.

section.title: Macintosh OS X

section.para: In the directory into which you extracted the Architect, run the command java -jar architect.jar . If you have a visual browser, you may be able to launch the architect by clicking (or double-clicking) on the architect.jar file.

section.title: Getting Started with Power*Matchmaker
section.para: Defining Database Types The tie-in between Drivers and Connections might seem a bit indirect if you are not used to using Java JDBC. In this section you are telling the Power*MatchMaker where the drivers are so that they can be used when necessary. Definition of the database type must be completed before a new database connection can be configured.

Clicking on the Manage Connections... button will open the Database Connection Manager window. In this window click on JBDC drivers button to define a database connection. The JDBC drivers window will appear as shown below.

The column on the left hand side contains a list of pre-defined database connection types. To connect to one of the pre-defined database connections you must first tell Power*Matchmaker where to find the JAR file. Highlight the desired database type in the left column, click on the Add JAR... button, and navigate to the correct JAR file for the database type. The Add JAR... and Remove JAR buttons are used to point the Power*Matchmaker to the locations of the JAR files that contain the proper JDBC Driver. Once, you select a JAR file, if there is a valid driver in it, a file tree will appear in the area below the buttons. This is a representation of the JAR file and its JDBC contents. Select the driver you wish to use and click the "OK" button at the bottom.

To edit the properties of the drivers click on the item in the list and edit the fields to the right. If you wish to create a database type that is not pre-defined,click on the + button in the lower left corner of the window. Type in the name of the Database connection, the Driver Class, and the Connection String Template (i.e. jbdc:...).

listitem.para: The "Name" field is used to assign a name to the database connection. It will appear in the column on the left. These names will also be used to assign a type to a new connection that you are defining.
The "Driver Class" is the class name of the driver.

section.para: Connection String Template Used to define a URL template. The URL template is used by the Power*MatchMaker to create a URL that is used to attempt a database connection. The pattern that the string must conform to is not trivial but is made up of two simpler parts, literals and variables. Literals are entered like normal text but may not contain angle brackets (< or >) because they are reserved for defining variables. As their name implies, literals appear in the URL in the same position and way they appear in the template. Variables are used to make it easier for things that change such as the schema or database name you wish to connect to. They are defined in the template by "<variable_name:default_value>". Once a variable is defined in the template, a field labeled with the variable's name will appear below with the default value in it just below the template as a preview to what you will later be able to modify in "Connection Properties".

Note: Default values are often useful, but are optional. If you do not want a variable to have a default value, define it as "<variable_name>". The default value for these variables is blank. For example, if we wanted to connect to a Microsoft SQL Server database, the URL template might look like "jdbc:sqlserver://<Hostname>:<Port:1433>". The URL this template will output is "jdbc:sqlserver://:1433" where the 1433 was a default value. If we were to enter "localhost" in the Hostname field, we would get the URL "jdbc:sqlserver://localhost:1433". By defining the "Hostname" variable, we make it easier and quicker to connect to a generic SQL Server instance. SQL Server databases listen to port 1433 by default but can be configured to listen to others so, by giving the variable this default, we can have the most common value inserted automatically while allowing us to modify what is in the field to change the port in specific cases.
Defining Database Connections In the “Database Connection Manager” window click on new to add a new connection.

listitem.para: "Connection Name" - This an arbitrary name for the database connection. It will appear in the left hand column of the Database Connection Manager window as well as in a drop down list on the Login window. Name the connection something that is easily identifiable for the next time you open up Power*MatchMaker.

"Database Type" - This is the type of database you wish to connect to. The database types must be defined before attempting to define the database connection with that type. All of the database types that have been defined will appear in a drop down list.

"Connect Options" - These options are the variables, such as schema and database name that can be modified to connect to the defined database types. They are the variables in the database type definition stage.

"Repository Schema Owner" - This field is only filled in if this database connection is the one to be written to, the repository database. The contents entered to this field will automatically become a prefix to the repository tables.

section.para: Once all the fields are completed click on the OK button. This will take you back to the Database Connection Manager window.

Login in to Power*Matchmaker From the Database Connection Manager window you can highlight the repository database connection and click on Login. If starting up a brand new session, the Power*MatchMaker Login window will automatically appear. Start by choosing the repository database connection you wish to work with. This will default the user id and password information that has been previously specified when setting up the database connection.

Power*Matchmaker has the capability to connect to multiple different databases in one session but it can only be connected to one repository database per session. The other database connections are automatically accessible due to the database connection definitions made earlier. You can open multiple sessions simultaneously to access different repositories.

section.title: Choosing a Database
section.para: Select a pre-configured database connection from the combo box. If you are using the Power*MatchMaker for the first time, you would want to setup a new database connection first in the Database Connection Manager.

section.title: User ID & Password
section.para: Enter your login user id and password in these corresponding text fields.

section.para: Click this button to open up the Database Connection Manager to manage and configure your database connections. If you are using the Power*MatchMaker for the first time, click here to configure your first database connection.

section.title: Login
section.para: Click this button to connect and login to the selected database. If you are using the Power*MatchMaker for the first time, you would need to setup a new database connection first.

section.title: Database Connection Manager
section.para: This is the window where you can manage and configure your database connections. The list on the left displays all your currently configured database connections.

section.title: New...
section.para: Click this button to create a new database connection. If you are using the Power*MatchMaker for the first time, click here.

section.title: Edit...
section.para: Click this button to edit the configurations of the selected database connection. If you are using the Power*MatchMaker for the first time, you would need to create a new database connection first.

section.title: Remove
section.para: Click this button to remove the selected database connection from your list of connections.

section.title: JDBC Drivers
section.para: Click this button to edit your JDBC drivers. If you are using a database with drivers that were not supplied with the Power*MatchMaker or wish to use different drivers than previously configured, click here.

section.title: Login
section.para: Click this button once you have configured a database connection and wish to connect and login to that database. It will bring you back to the Login Window with the specified database connection selected.

section.title: Database Connection Window
section.para: This is the window where you can set the specific settings for a database connection.

section.title: Connection Name
section.para: Enter an arbitrary name for the database connection. It will appear in the left hand column of the Database Connection Manager window as well as in a drop down list on the Login window. Name the connection something that is easily identifiable for the next time you open up Power*MatchMaker.

section.title: Database Type
section.para: Select the type of database you wish to connect to. The database types must be defined before attempting to define the database connection with that type. All of the database types that have been defined will appear in a drop down list.

section.title: Connect Options & JDBC URL
section.para: These two text fields work together to form an URL that is used by the Power*MatchMaker to connect to the database. The text entered in the Connect Options fields replace the corresponding variables as defined by the database type to form the URL. Modify either text fields to form the URL.

section.title: Username & Password
section.para: Enter your login username and password in the corresponding text fields.

section.title: Repository Schema Owner
section.para: Fill this text field only if this database connection connects to the repository database. The contents entered in this field will automatically become a prefix to the repository tables.

section.title: JDBC Drivers Window
section.para: This is the window where you can specific the JDBC drivers to use for each database type. A specification for a database type must be completed here before creating a database connection of that type.

section.title: Selecting a Database Type
section.para: You can choose to modify a database type's specifications by selecting it on the list to the left. If your database type does not exist on the list, click the + button under the list to add a new database type. If your database type was not supported by the Power*MatchMaker, click this + button to add it.

section.title: Name
section.para: Enter in this text field to assign a name to the database type. A database type's name is used when assigning a type to a database connection.

section.title: Driver Class
section.para: Enter the Java class name of the driver in this text field.

section.title: Connection String Template
section.para: Enter the string template that will be used by database connections of this type to generate JDBC URLs in this field. The pattern of a template should consist of two simpler parts: literals and variables. Literals are entered as is and will appear in the URL in exactly the same form. Variables are surrounded by < and > and will take the corresponding values as specified in the database connection settings to form the URL. An example for an Oracle database would be jdbc:oracle:thin:@<hostname>:<Port:1521>:<SID>.

section.title: JAR Settings
section.para: The JDBC driver files of a database type needed to connect to a database are contained in JAR files. Use the Add JAR... and Remove JAR buttons to add or remove the JAR files containing the required JDBC driver class file.

section.title: New De-dupe Project
section.para: De-dupe projects are used to find duplicates of records in a table. For example if a customer database contained information on a Joe Smith and a Joeseph Smith, this project would help you determine if that customer was the same person and merge them if they are. There are 3 basic steps to create this type of Match project; 1. Define Munge Processes, 2. Run the engine, 3. Validate Matches.

listitem.para: "Match ID", the name of the match project you are creating. This field must be filled in to create a match project. It can be any combination of characters.
"Folder", designates in which folder you would like the match project to be saved to.

section.para: Enter the Source Table; schema, and table name. The Unique Index field will automatically be populated and the Filter field is optional. The source table is the table that is to be De-duped.
Enter the Output Table; schema and table name. The output table is the table to be written to.

Once all the fields have been filled click on the save button near the bottom of the screen and the new project will appear in the Power*Matchmaker tree. The match project created in the picture below was named Trial. Once a new project is created some files are automatically created.
